snippet: A professor says he has found something closer to definitive proof that some 325 lines in the 1602 quarto edition of Thomas Kyd’s play “The Spanish Tragedy” were indeed written by Shakespeare.
abstract: University of Texas Professor Douglas Bruster says he has found something closer to definitive proof that part of Thomas Kyd's play The Spanish Tragedy was written by Shakespeare; in paper to be published in journal Notes and Queries, Bruster argues various idiosyncratic features of the Additional Passages--including some awkward lines that strike doubters as distinctly sub-Shakespearean--may be explained as print shop misreadings of Shakespeare’s penmanship.
lead_paragraph: A professor says he has found something closer to definitive proof that some 325 lines in the 1602 quarto edition of Thomas Kyd’s play “The Spanish Tragedy” were indeed written by Shakespeare.

headline.seo: Further Proof of Shakespeare’s Hand in ‘The Spanish Tragedy’
headline.main: Much Ado About Who: Is It Really Shakespeare?
headline.print_headline: Much Ado About Who: Is It Really Shakespeare?
